liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Analysis by 7.30 reporter Nadia Daly Ahead of the vote this weekend I've been taking a look at the state of play in Victoria. It's often seen as one of the more progressive states and for a while it was one of a few that was leaning towards a Yes majority in the polls. That's now changed, according to all but one opinion poll. They're now projecting a No vote will win in Victoria. It's worth noting opinion polls have their limitation and can be wrong (and have been in the past). I spoke to Victorian lobbyist and pollster Kos Samaras about why there has been a shift in the state. He told me it's being driven by Melbourne's outer suburbs, where the Yes campaign has been less visible (compared to inner city suburbs where the Yes vote is much higher) and where some voters aren't finding the case for voting Yes succinct or clear enough. Additionally, he said some areas with higher migrant populations in the state were only being handed campaign pamphlets in English. And Kos said that when people don't understand, they're more likely to vote No. But the Yes campaign is staying positive and they are hopeful the many undecided voters will be swayed towards a Yes in the coming days. I'll have more on 7.30 tonight.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A look at Victoria's state of play

children.content: Analysis by 7.30 reporter Nadia Daly
Ahead of the vote this weekend I've been taking a look at the state of play in Victoria.
It's often seen as one of the more progressive states and for a while it was one of a few that was leaning towards a Yes majority in the polls.

That's now changed, according to all but one opinion poll. They're now projecting a No vote will win in Victoria. It's worth noting opinion polls have their limitation and can be wrong (and have been in the past).

props.alt: A Vote Yes and Vote No sign side by side.

children.content: (AAP: Esther Linder)
I spoke to Victorian lobbyist and pollster
Kos Samaras
about why there has been a shift in the state.
He told me it's
being driven by Melbourne's outer suburbs,
where the Yes campaign has been
less visible
(compared to inner city suburbs where the Yes vote is much higher) and where some voters aren't finding the case for voting Yes
succinct or clear enough.
Additionally, he said some areas with higher migrant populations in the state were only being
handed campaign pamphlets in English.
And Kos said that when people don't understand, they're more likely to vote No.
But the Yes campaign is staying positive and they are hopeful the many undecided voters will be swayed towards a Yes in the coming days.
I'll have more on 7.30 tonight.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporter Viki Ntafillis has been speaking to South Australians casting their votes at pre-polling sites around Adelaide. At one venue in the CBD, everyone who spoke to the ABC said they were voting Yes. Michael Morrow said while he was originally planning to vote No, some of the "aggressive" campaigning "kind of put me off a little bit". "I just thought about and decided vote Yes," he said. He said he chatted to family about the referendum, but his decision was personal and "wasn't really influenced by anybody else". "If it can help out, might as well [vote Yes]," he said. Fiona Futo said she voted a "definite Yes" and held back tears as she spoke, saying she felt "a little bit emotional about it". "I just think Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have really suffered a lot … just anything we can do to help make things better, I definitely want to support that ," she said. She said while she was unsure exactly how the Voice to Parliament would work, she trusted elected officials. "It is quite confusing, but I don't know what happens in Parliament House, I don't know how our day-to-day decisions are made and all the processes that happen in government but I just trust that our elected government does know how all that works and that they have made a plan of how the Voice is going to work," she said. "And I don't need to worry about that, I just need to know about whether or not I want to do the right thing to support Aboriginal people."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We popped by a polling station in Adelaide

children.content: Reporter Viki Ntafillis has been speaking to South Australians casting their votes at pre-polling sites around Adelaide.

He said he chatted to family about the referendum, but his decision was personal and "wasn't really influenced by anybody else".
"If it can help out, might as well [vote Yes]," he said.
Fiona Futo said she voted a "definite Yes" and held back tears as she spoke, saying she felt "a little bit emotional about it".

(ABC News: Viki Ntafillis )
"I just think Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have really suffered a lot …
just anything we can do to help make things better, I definitely want to support that
," she said.
She said while she was unsure exactly how the Voice to Parliament would work, she trusted elected officials.

"It is quite confusing, but I don't know what happens in Parliament House, I don't know how our day-to-day decisions are made and all the processes that happen in government but I just trust that our elected government does know how all that works and that they have made a plan of how the Voice is going to work," she said.
"And I don't need to worry about that, I just need to know about whether or not I want to do the right thing to support Aboriginal people."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Independent senator and progressive No figurehead Lidia Thorpe said a No result in Saturday's Voice referendum would be the start of a "healing journey" for the country. "I see that as a victory for the Blak sovereign movement that have resisted colonisation for 200 years," she said. "This would be a beginning of a real healing journey and a truth-telling journey that this country must take before anybody makes any decisions on us, without us. "I think there’s lots to look forward to." Last Thursday, Senator Thorpe made allegations that Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and the AFP were not doing enough to protect her from far-right extremism after being the target of an offensive video. Senator Thorpe told RN's Patricia Karvelas that she believes the referendum "gave platform for the racists". "The racism we've seen, the far-right Nazis coming out. All the bad behaviour from a lot of sections of our country, is part of an illness in this country that needs to be healed," she said. "This is the government’s fault, this is Anthony Albanese’s fault we're seeing a rise in racism, we're seeing families split, we've seen communities divided." "We should never have gone to this referendum in the first place." Listen to the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No result would be a 'victory' for Blak sovereign movement, says Lidia Thorpe

featuredLink.title: How will Saturday's outcome impact reconciliation? - ABC listen

children.content: Independent senator and progressive No figurehead
Lidia Thorpe
said a No result in Saturday's Voice referendum would be the start of a "healing journey" for the country.
"I see that as a victory for the Blak sovereign movement that have resisted colonisation for 200 years," she said.
"This would be a beginning of a real healing journey and a truth-telling journey that this country must take before anybody makes any decisions on us, without us.
"I think there’s lots to look forward to."
Last Thursday, Senator Thorpe made allegations
that
Prime Minister
Anthony Albanese
and the AFP were not doing enough to protect her from far-right extremism after being the target of an offensive video.
Senator Thorpe told RN's
Patricia Karvelas
that she believes the referendum "gave platform for the racists".
"The racism we've seen, the far-right Nazis coming out. All the bad behaviour from a lot of sections of our country, is part of an illness in this country that needs to be healed," she said.
"This is the government’s fault, this is Anthony Albanese’s fault we're seeing a rise in racism, we're seeing families split, we've seen communities divided."
"We should never have gone to this referendum in the first place."
Listen to the full interview below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matthew Doran. The head of Australia's domestic spy agency ASIO has warned the conflict between Israel and Gaza is "resonating in the Australian community", although the local terror threat is unchanged. Director-General Mike Burgess has issued a rare public statement in the wake of fiery protests across Australia, noting such activity will continue "and are likely to feature strong emotive claims." He says ASIO is carefully monitoring the situation along with police. "I remain concerned about the potential for opportunistic violence with little or no warning," Mr Burgess said. "However, it is important to distinguish opportunistic violence from planned violence or acts of terrorism. "ASIO remains well-placed to detect threats to security including potential acts of politically motivated violence or the promotion of communal violence." Mr Burgess also urged people taking part in protests, and commenting on them, to be careful about the tone they strike – noting that "words matter". "It is important that all parties consider the implications for social cohesion when making public statements. "ASIO has seen direct connections between inflamed language and inflamed community tensions. "As always, ASIO is not interested in those who are engaged in lawful protest, but rather the small subset of protesters who may wish to escalate protest to violence—this includes religiously motivated and ideologically motivated extremists, or anyone who believes that violence is a means to further their own interests."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASIO warns conflict between Israel and Gaza is 'resonating in Australian community'

children.content: Reporting by Matthew Doran.
The head of Australia's domestic spy agency
ASIO
has warned the conflict between Israel and Gaza is "resonating in the Australian community", although the local terror threat is unchanged.
Director-General Mike Burgess
has issued a rare public statement in the wake of fiery protests across Australia, noting such activity will continue "and are likely to feature strong emotive claims."
He says
ASIO is carefully monitoring the situation along with police.
"I remain concerned about the potential for opportunistic violence with little or no warning," Mr Burgess said.
"However, it is important to distinguish opportunistic violence from planned violence or acts of terrorism.
"ASIO remains well-placed to detect threats to security including potential acts of politically motivated violence or the promotion of communal violence."
Mr Burgess also urged people taking part in protests, and commenting on them, to be careful about the tone they strike – noting that "words matter".
"It is important that all parties consider the implications for social cohesion when making public statements.
"ASIO has seen direct connections between inflamed language and inflamed community tensions.

"As always, ASIO is not interested in those who are engaged in lawful protest, but rather the small subset of protesters who may wish to escalate protest to violence—this includes religiously motivated and ideologically motivated extremists, or anyone who believes that violence is a means to further their own interests."

props.alt: Image of Mike Burgess wearing a suit

children.content: ASIO Director-General Mike Burgess said that 'words matter.'
(ABC News: Nicholas Haggarty)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The world's largest gold producer Newmont reports 96% of shareholder votes were cast in favour of its proposed $26.2 billion acquisition of Australian gold miner Newcrest Mining. In May, Newcrest backed the takeover offer from Newmont. Newcrest shareholders will vote tomorrow. The deal will become Newmont's third-largest deal ever involving an Australian company. Both the companies expect the deal to close in early November .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Gold play: Newmont Newcrest acquisition all but done deal

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Two big things happened today, one predictable, one surprising. 'Bad apples' The clear difference between the new CEO of PwC Australia — imported from Singapore in recent months — is the willingness to blame former leaders for wrongdoing. Repeatedly, Kevin Burrowes laid the blame for failings on former CEOs Luke Sayers (2012-2020) and Tom Seymour (2020-2023). Mr Seymour did not appear before the hearings today. Greens senator Barbara Pocock put it to the current CEO that it was bad leadership, forming a certain culture, that led to bad outcomes. POCOCK: "Switkowski's main finding is that the PwC scandal arose because of the firm's pursuit of revenue at any cost, a 'whatever it takes' culture, and a system in relation to revenue putting profit above ethics. While a small number of bad apples have been sacrificed or suffered a penalty of some form, the system persists... none of the proposed measures will fix the problem. They're window dressing. They exhort people to behave ethically, when the overwhelming requirement of the business model is to chase the business to make revenue. How do you propose to change your business model? BURROWES (New CEO): "I would agree with your characterization of the firm historically, certainly. I think that's clear. And we need to change because that's not acceptable. It's not the way we should be doing business." Mr Sayers apologised overall but specifically blamed "a number of bad actor tax partners, bad actor tax partners that behaviourally made the wrong choices" who had shared confidential information. Misled? A persistent line of questioning — and a future headache for the firm — was about a plan to sell the business. The idea was created by former PwC boss Luke Sayers sometime around 2017-19 to spin-off the Australian, New Zealand and some of the Asian-based management consulting arms of the firm. The plan was advanced enough that Mr Sayers travelled to the US to push the idea, with a mooted figure he couldn't recall but was noted in the inquiry to be $1 billion. The deal never came off. The reason for the questions was only revealed by Labor senator Deborah O'Neill at the end of the hearing. Around the time of the deal, the Senate had been examining audits and consulting firms. A PwC Australia submission pushing back on the idea of 'structurally separating' the audit and consulting businesses rubbished it as unworkable and impossible. But according to responses today, at the same time Mr Sayers and PwC Australia were actively shopping this idea. If proven, it would mean PwC staff were saying one thing to the Senate and an entirely different thing to the market ...
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PwC may have misled the Senate

children.content: Two big things happened today, one predictable, one surprising.
'Bad apples'
The clear difference between the new CEO of PwC Australia — imported from Singapore in recent months — is the willingness to blame former leaders for wrongdoing.
Repeatedly, Kevin Burrowes laid the blame for failings on former CEOs Luke Sayers (2012-2020) and Tom Seymour (2020-2023).
Mr Seymour did not appear before the hearings today.
Greens senator Barbara Pocock put it to the current CEO that it was bad leadership, forming a certain culture, that led to bad outcomes.

POCOCK: "Switkowski's main finding is that the PwC scandal arose because of the firm's pursuit of revenue at any cost, a 'whatever it takes' culture, and a system in relation to revenue putting profit above ethics. While a small number of bad apples have been sacrificed or suffered a penalty of some form, the system persists... none of the proposed measures will fix the problem. They're window dressing. They exhort people to behave ethically, when the overwhelming requirement of the business model is to chase the business to make revenue. How do you propose to change your business model?

BURROWES (New CEO): "I would agree with your characterization of the firm historically, certainly. I think that's clear. And we need to change because that's not acceptable. It's not the way we should be doing business."
Mr Sayers apologised overall but specifically blamed "a number of bad actor tax partners, bad actor tax partners that behaviourally made the wrong choices" who had shared confidential information.
Misled?
A persistent line of questioning — and a future headache for the firm — was about a plan to sell the business.
The idea was created by former PwC boss Luke Sayers sometime around 2017-19 to spin-off the Australian, New Zealand and some of the Asian-based management consulting arms of the firm.
The plan was advanced enough that Mr Sayers travelled to the US to push the idea, with a mooted figure he couldn't recall but was noted in the inquiry to be $1 billion. The deal never came off.
The reason for the questions was only revealed by Labor senator Deborah O'Neill at the end of the hearing.
Around the time of the deal, the Senate had been examining audits and consulting firms.
A PwC Australia submission pushing back on the idea of 'structurally separating' the audit and consulting businesses rubbished it as unworkable and impossible.
But according to responses today, at the same time Mr Sayers and PwC Australia were actively shopping this idea.
If proven, it would mean PwC staff were saying one thing to the Senate and an entirely different thing to the market ...

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Demons have released a statement, confirming earlier reports that Clayton Oliver spent a short time in hopital earlier today. "The Melbourne Football Club can confirm that Clayton Oliver was admitted to hospital. "Clayton was transported to hospital via ambulance, following a medical episode. "The hospital completed a number of tests and Clayton has since been discharged from hospital and is recovering at home. "The Club will continue to work with Clayton and his medical support team to ensure he receives all the necessary treatment. "We ask that media respect Clayton's privacy at this time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Clayton Oliver recovering after 'medical episode': Melbourne

children.content: (Getty Images)
The Demons have released a statement, confirming earlier reports that Clayton Oliver spent a short time in hopital earlier today.
"The Melbourne Football Club can confirm that Clayton Oliver was admitted to hospital.
"Clayton was transported to hospital via ambulance, following a medical episode.
"The hospital completed a number of tests and Clayton has since been discharged from hospital and is recovering at home.
"The Club will continue to work with Clayton and his medical support team to ensure he receives all the necessary treatment.
"We ask that media respect Clayton's privacy at this time."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We are continuing our look ahead to the draft class of 2023 with a glance at another Tasmanian midfielder destined for the top 10. Ryley Sanders is a big-bodied workhorse in midfield who dominated his under-18 year with his combination of inside grunt and outside skill. The Larke Medallist teamed up with Colby McKercher to lead the Allies to victory in the state champs and enjoyed a fantastic season with the Sandringham Dragons. He proved a commanding presence in midfield, a real leader of both sides, and quickly became a favourite among draft watchers. It's a stretch to say he plays like him, but with the blonde hair and pulled-up socks he does genuinely look like Jason Horne-Francis when he plays. He doesn't have the explosive athleticism of Horne-Francis, but he does move a bit like him and makes up for that lack of top-level pace with a fantastic work ethic. He's a little more one-paced than someone like McKercher, but he's quick enough. And when he's frame fills out further he could well be a force for any AFL midfield. North Melbourne are big fans and tried to get the AFL to let them have priority access to him via their NGA, but Sanders is available to all and sundry on the open market.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Draft Spotlight — Ryley Sanders

children.content: We are continuing our look ahead to the draft class of 2023 with a glance at another Tasmanian midfielder destined for the top 10.
Ryley Sanders is a big-bodied workhorse in midfield who dominated his under-18 year with his combination of inside grunt and outside skill.
(Getty Images)

The Larke Medallist teamed up with Colby McKercher to lead the Allies to victory in the state champs and enjoyed a fantastic season with the Sandringham Dragons. He proved a commanding presence in midfield, a real leader of both sides, and quickly became a favourite among draft watchers.

It's a stretch to say he plays like him, but with the blonde hair and pulled-up socks he does genuinely look like Jason Horne-Francis when he plays. He doesn't have the explosive athleticism of Horne-Francis, but he does move a bit like him and makes up for that lack of top-level pace with a fantastic work ethic.
(Getty Images)
He's a little more one-paced than someone like McKercher, but he's quick enough. And when he's frame fills out further he could well be a force for any AFL midfield.
North Melbourne are big fans and tried to get the AFL to let them have priority access to him via their NGA, but Sanders is available to all and sundry on the open market.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The future number one draft pick was on SEN WA this morning, and had a very clear message to Eagles fans — and the rest of the competition — when it comes to his preparedness to head west. "To all the Eagles fans listening, I don't know how many times I have to say this. "I'm happy to go to the Eagles and grateful to be in the position I am. I'll happily come west and wear number 9." Cousins. Naitanui. Reid? If the Eagles do trade the number one pick, it won't be because Reid is a flight risk.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Harley Reid: West Coast's number 9?

children.content: (Getty Images)
The future number one draft pick was on SEN WA this morning, and had a very clear message to Eagles fans — and the rest of the competition — when it comes to his preparedness to head west.
"To all the Eagles fans listening, I don't know how many times I have to say this.
"I'm happy to go to the Eagles and grateful to be in the position I am. I'll happily come west and wear number 9."
Cousins. Naitanui. Reid?
If the Eagles do trade the number one pick, it won't be because Reid is a flight risk.

items.synopsis: Police charge a 23-year-old man with intimidation after four teens were allegedly threatened for displaying an Israeli flag across their car in Sydney's eastern suburbs.

title.children: Minister calls man's alleged threat to teens who were displaying Israeli flag 'anti-Semitic'

image.altText: A family of four smiling

items.synopsis: Hundreds of caravans and camper trailers crash every year. Police in Queensland say about 90 per cent of recreational vehicles weigh too much, creating a safety hazard and potentially voiding the owners' insurance.

title.children: Rob loves camping in his caravan, but a check found something simple putting his family's safety at risk

image.altText: Two men put ballot papers into a box.

items.synopsis: The crisis in Israel is unlikely to directly shift votes one way or another in the Australian Voice referendum, but it does make it harder for the Yes campaign to be heard at precisely the time it needs to be, writes David Speers.

title.children: With days left for the Voice campaign, it just got harder for Yes and Albanese to break through

image.altText: Seb and Ella McCorry

items.synopsis: Sebastian and Ella McCorry, 18, are helping their fellow students get the right information ahead of the Voice referendum poll, amid concern about inaccurate social media posts.

title.children: These twin high-schoolers say misinformation on the Voice is rampant among teens, so they're trying to fix that

image.altText: Alyssa Healy bats to the leg side against West Indies in Brisbane.

items.synopsis: The West Indies battled their way to just 83 in the first one-day international in Brisbane, so they will be hoping for a big improvement against Australia at Junction Oval. Check out the live scores and stats in our ScoreCentre.

title.children: ODI live: Shortened clash between Australia and West Indies finally underway after rain delay
